titleStmt.title: A pretended voice from heaven, proved to bee the voice of man, and not of God. Or, An answer to a treatise, called A voice from heaven, written by Mr. Gualter Postlethwait, an unordained preacher, taking upon him to exercise the pastoral charge, in a congregation at Lewis in Sussex. Wherein, his weakness, in undertaking to prove all protestant churches to bee antichristian, and to bee separated from, as no true churches of Christ, is discovered; and the sinfulness of such a separation evinced. Together with, a brief answer inserted, to the arguments for popular ordination, brought by the answerers of Jus Divinum Ministerii Evangelici, in their book called The preacher sent. By Ezekiel Charke, M.A. and rector of Waldron in Sussex. Imprimatur, Edmond Calamy.
titleStmt.author: Charke, Ezekiel.

publicationStmt.publisher: printed for Andrew Kembe, and are to bee sold at his shop at St. Margarets-hill, near the Talbot in Southwark, and under St. Margarets church on New-Fishstreet-hill,

notesStmt.note: With a final leaf of advertisement.
Errata on final page of advertisement.
A reply to: Postlethwaite, Walter "A voice from heaven".
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
